thread.title: The Hashtag #DisabledandCute Proves Anyone Can Be Disabled, Cute, *And* Sassy
thread.title_full: The Hashtag #DisabledandCute Proves Anyone Can Be Disabled, Cute, *And* Sassy

author: Cosmopolitan.com
title: The Hashtag #DisabledandCute Proves Anyone Can Be Disabled, Cute, *And* Sassy
text:
Like many women, Keah Brown, a 25-year-old journalist from Lockport, New York, sometimes suffers from body insecurity. That she has cerebral palsy, a condition that can affect a person's movement, muscle tone, coordination, and posture, doesn't help. "There is a common misconception that disabled people are not attractive," she says. "We are often seen as undesirable and broken."
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below On Feb. 12, Keah was feeling particularly cute and confident. She decided to tweet a selfie using the hashtag #DisabledAndCute, "because you can be both [disabled and cute], it's not like one negates the other," she says.
I want to shoutout my Disabled brothers, sisters, & non-binary folks! W/ #DisabledAndCute pic.twitter.com/Qcx5mvc1UI
— Keah Brown (@Keah_Maria) February 12, 2017 To better prove this point, she called on others to share photos of themselves that made them proud. While Keah wasn't exactly expecting her tweet to start a thing, #DisabledAndCute took off: People with both visible and invisible disabilities, of different races, sexual orientations, and genders, responded by posting their own photos with Keah's hashtag, on Twitter and beyond.
#DisabledandCute cutest shawty with RA you'll see (hands don't always work but I keep em up) pic.twitter.com/qJ2rleKpKO
— 9ine (@noshaidah) February 15, 2017 Advertisement - Continue Reading Below
#DisabledandCute Shoutout to all my ♿️ sisters out here pic.twitter.com/TXsEJHk6U6
— Unruly ♿️ (@Eliza_Heidi) February 12, 2017 Advertisement - Continue Reading Below Celebrating body positivity, acceptance, visibility & joy with #DisabledAndCute "you're so brave" nah, I'm just dope #disabled #SayTheWord #bodypositive #plussizefashion #bbw #effyourbeautystandards #bodypositivity #plussize #disability #amputee #disabilitypride #wheelchair #curvygirl #curvy #gabifreshxswimsexy #disabledrightsarehumanrights
A post shared by Danielle Perez (@divadelux) on Feb 12, 2017 at 7:17pm PST
#disabledandcute I'd prefer handsome, but cute will suffice. ♿️ pic.twitter.com/AMEcS7zday
— Ajani 'AJ' Murray (@gotnextaj) February 15, 2017 #DisabledandCute is an actual hashtag yasss I love it. I only use my chair part-time but always make sure I look sassy in it. pic.twitter.com/UMJ9NMC2bN
— Poppy Akinola (@PoppyAkinola) February 13, 2017 Advertisement - Continue Reading Below #disabledandcute , howbow dah? pic.twitter.com/Hpmrbu70nn
— Marina Carlos (@MarinaCpom) February 12, 2017 #disabledandcute you rang? pic.twitter.com/AvnSuCGCXQ
— Jasmine Stairs (@snazel) February 12, 2017 Advertisement - Continue Reading Below #disabledandcute hell yeah I am pic.twitter.com/WPOZGXecer
— Corinne Duyvis (@corinneduyvis) February 12, 2017 Oh hey, did someone ( @Keah_Maria ) say #DisabledandCute ? Because... pic.twitter.com/dTTya3838m
— Kayla Whaley (@PunkinOnWheels) February 12, 2017 "The proof of pride is in the pictures," she says of her hashtag's success.
People without disabilities even began sharing photos of others, including pictures of their disabled kids and siblings, although Keah did tweet a warning to be mindful of disabled people's privacy by first obtaining their permission. After all, not everyone wants to broadcast their business.
#disabledandcute i'm so glad to see the tag doing well but a reminder that it's uncool to post people's pictures without their permission.
— Keah Brown (@Keah_Maria) February 15, 2017 For her part, Keah doesn't feel like she has anything to hide. "My disability is not all that I am, but it is a big part of who I am," she says. "I will never not be disabled, and so to [conceal] that part of me would be ridiculous."
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below Now, Keah hopes the hashtag triggers real conversations. "My hope is that this hashtag helps mainstream media and other able-bodied people see how much disabled people have to offer and understand that we are more than inspiration porn and people to pity," she says. "In fact, we have so much talent we just need the opportunity to showcase what we can do."
The #DisabledAndCute hashtag is just one such opportunity. Here's to hoping it's the first of many.
Looking through #DisabledAndCute and loving all these people pic.twitter.com/0p2eddXVpc
— xx (@robbxx2) February 15, 2017 Get all the ~FiTsPiRaTiOn~ directly in your feed. Follow Facebook.com/CosmoBod .
